image_text: Drought years: Very little rain or snow flowing into the Oroville reservoir.
2017: Big storms bring big inflows to the reservoir.
Drought years: Low outflow because California was hoarding all of the water Oroville could store.
2017: Continued low outflow of water for months despite high water levels.
Reservoir levels: The reservoir was nearly full in mid-February, when the storm broke.
Four ways to outflow water from the reservoir: All were unequal to the outflow needed due to the storm and high reservoir levels. Let's look at each in more depth.
The emergency spillway: Used for the first time during the storm but the hillside began dangerously eroding within a day.
Main spillway: Damaged February 7 and releasing reduced flow to prevent further damage.
Edward Hyatt Powerplant: Non-operational; turned off to prevent damage to it after the main spillway was damaged.
River outlet: Rarely used since a 2009 accident that injured dam workers. Now releasing up to 2,000 cfs.
This caused quite a bit of damage.

text: Disaster averted? How did we avoid a crisis? I don't really know the answer to this question but I hope someone does.
What's next? I think we should all just hope that the rain stops and we go back to normal California weather.
